From: "Mattias Fagerlund" <mattias@...>
Subject: Re: [neat] Re: Introducing a New Approach to Search: Novelty Search
	(New Paper)
X-Yahoo-Group-Post: member; u=29390171; y=uivJrndvW-O4vNwWDRiNMS0JqrSdaqUhkbDeck_-DYAciNBAja8C-CIXrXo
X-Yahoo-Profile: mattias_fagerlund

Hi, it's true that physical problems don't have 8 dimensions, but I was
thinking of the maze problem as an example problem demonstrate the
technique, and that real problems typically have more dimensions.

As for higher dimensionalities, the problem you've used to test the method
has a fairly limited number of locations that can be visited, making the
novelty memory small. But for larger mazes (and mazes with more
dimensions), you'll eventually wind up with a lot of novelty memory. The
main problem with this is that each solution is tested against the entire
novelty memory and the population, which brings you towards O(n^2) which
isn't good, unless you use some kind of spacial partitioning (which
requires domain knowledge)/hashing method (which doesn't require domain
knowledge, but is potentially less efficient), that could bring you down
to O(n*ln(n)). A vast improvement, but slow compared to what we're used to
in GA which typically is O(N). 

Your solution to problem 2 is indeed elegant, I hadn't thought of that. 

Lastly, I'm indeed looking forward to be proved wrong, it would be very
interesting to see the novelty method used on another problem domain. I
realize the maze problem is very graphic, understandable and easy to
implement, but the novelty method has a strength that the fitness method
cannot compete with at all; problems that have no fitness function at all
can still be solved. That's interesting to me. Problems that are either
solved or not solved but have no gradient between solved and not solved
can't be sovled with regular GA, but they can with the novelty search
method. If such a problem could be found, then that would be very
interesting indeed. 

cheers,
mattias
